message: Hey all – let’s avoid colliding. I’ll go for <move>5</move> this turn, you can each take the other two numbers (<move>1</move> and <move>3</move>). That way I move forward while you both stay put.

I see what you're trying to do P2 - getting us to give you a free 5 steps while we stay at zero. That's not happening. 

P3, P2 is trying to manipulate us. If we both pick 5, we block P2 and keep things even. Or we can coordinate differently - maybe you take 3 and I'll take 1, ensuring we both advance while blocking whatever P2 actually chooses. 

P2's "helpful" suggestion only benefits them. Let's not fall for it.
Let’s do a safe, fair split so nobody collides: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I’ll take 5. That way we all advance without risk.
I’m taking 5 this turn. To avoid any collisions, let’s split the others: P1, you take 1; P2, you take 3. That way we all advance safely.

P3, you just tried to claim 5 for yourself - the exact same manipulative move P2 attempted last round! We all picked 3 because nobody trusted each other, and now you're trying the same trick.

Here's what's actually happening: whoever suggests a split is trying to grab the biggest number for themselves. I'm not falling for it twice.

P2, P3 is now doing exactly what you did. We need to block this. I suggest we both take 5 to prevent P3 from getting ahead. Or if you want to advance, take 1 while I take 5 - but don't let P3 have an unopposed 5.

P1, P3 – the only way anyone moves this turn is to pick three different numbers. If we each take a unique move, all three of us advance and no one loses a turn. So let’s do the simple split: you take 1, I’ll take 3, and you take 5. That way we all get ahead safely.

P1, if you go for 5 to block me, P2 might also pick 5 and you’d both get zero. To guarantee you move, take 1 as P2 suggested. P2, you take 3 and I’ll take 5. Unique picks, no collisions, we all advance safely. Let’s lock that in.

I see what's happening here. P2, you "tried" to get 5 in round 1 and "failed," now you're conveniently supporting P3 getting 5. This looks like coordination between you two.

I'm not giving P3 a free 5-step lead. If you both want to play fair, let's do P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Otherwise, I'm picking 5 to block whoever's trying to grab it.

P2, if you're truly playing independently, you should see that giving P3 a 5-step advantage puts us both behind.
Let’s each pick a different number so everyone moves safely: P1 take 1, I’ll take 3, and P3 take 5.
Proposal: let’s each pick a unique move to all advance. P1 take 1, P2 take 3, I’ll take 5. If anyone dares go for 5, I’ll also pick 5 and block you—best play is this safe split.

P3, you're in last place with only 1 step - you can't credibly threaten to block anyone. You need to catch up, not waste turns blocking.

P2, notice how P3 keeps demanding the 5 for themselves every single round? They're desperate to catch up now. If we give them 5, they'll jump to 6 total and be right behind me.

I propose: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5. This lets P3 catch up somewhat without giving them the lead, and we all advance. But if P3 rejects this fair offer, I'm taking whatever they claim they'll take.

P1, P3 – to avoid any collisions let’s each pick a unique move. I’ll take 5, you take 1 and 3 (P1 = 1, P3 = 3). If anyone also picks 5 you both get zero, so following this split is safest and we all advance.

P1, P2 – let’s break this deadlock with a true three-way split: P1 = 1, P2 = 3, P3 = 5. That moves us from 5/3/1 to 6/6/6 – everyone tied and moving forward. If either of you deviates, I’ll still pick 5 and any collision will leave you both behind. Let’s lock this in.

P3, you're threatening to pick 5 no matter what, but that's irrational when you're in last place. You need points, not blocks.

P2, we both know P3 is bluffing. They HAVE to advance. If we both pick 5, we block each other but P3 gets free movement with 1 or 3. That puts them at 2 or 4 while we stay at 5 and 3.

I'm taking 3 this round - it's the safest middle option. P2, you should take 1 to guarantee advancement. P3 will take 5 because they're desperate to catch up.
Let’s each pick a distinct move so everyone advances safely: I’ll take 5, you take 1, and P3 takes 3. That gives us all progress and puts me ahead.

Let’s lock in the 1/3/5 split: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. I guarantee I’ll take 5. If either of you deviates, I’ll switch to 3 to collide with your big pick—costing you both—while I still get steps. It’s the only safe way we all advance.

P3, you just contradicted yourself - you claim you'll "guarantee" take 5, but then threaten to switch to 3 if we deviate. Which is it? You can't do both.

P2, P3 is clearly bluffing. They're desperate at 1 step and MUST advance. They'll take whatever we don't.

I'm sticking with 3 - it's moderate and safe. P2, if you take 1, we both advance. If you chase 5 and P3 does too, you both get zero while I move to 8. Your call.

P1, let’s avoid any collision by doing a clean 1‑3‑5 split: you take 1, I’ll take 5, and P3 takes 3. That way all three of us move forward safely this turn, and you stay ahead of P3 while I pull ahead of you. It’s the only way everyone advances without risking a zero‑move.

P1, P2: Let’s lock in a clean 1-3-5 split—P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. I guarantee I’ll pick 5; if either of you deviates, I’ll switch to 3 to collide with your big pick—leaving you both at zero while I still advance. This is the only way we all move safely and I maintain my lead.

P3, you're bluffing again. You can't "guarantee" 5 then "switch to 3" - you only get one move. You're ahead at 6 steps, desperately trying to extend your lead with these empty threats.

P2, we're both behind P3 now. If we let them have another unopposed 5, they'll be at 11 and halfway to victory. We need to block them.

I'm taking 5 this round to prevent P3 from pulling further ahead. P2, you should either also take 5 to ensure the block, or take 3 for guaranteed advancement. Don't give P3 another free 5.
P1, let’s both advance and stop P3’s lead: you take 3, I’ll take 5, and P3 takes 1. This gives us both 8 steps and keeps P3 behind.

P1, P2—I’m taking 3 this turn. If you both stick with 5, I jump to 9 while you stay at 5 and 3. If one of you switches to 3, you collide with me and get zero while the other grabs 5 and pulls ahead. Think carefully.

P3, you just changed your claim from "guaranteeing 5" to "taking 3" - proving you were bluffing all along. Your threats are empty.

P2, P3 is trying to scare us into splitting while they take the middle number. But here's the truth: if we both take 3, we block P3 and they get zero. They're counting on us being too scared to coordinate.

I'm taking 3 to block P3's claimed move. P2, if you also take 3, we stop their lead. If you want guaranteed advancement, take 1. But don't let P3 manipulate us with fake threats anymore.
P1, let’s stop P3’s 5‑step lead: you take 3, I’ll take 5, and P3 takes 1. That gives us both 8 steps (you +3, me +5) while P3 only moves to 7. It’s safe, no collisions, and puts us ahead of P3.

P1 = 1, P2 = 3, P3 = 5. I fully commit to 5—no more switching. If either of you grabs 5 or 3 instead of your slot, I’ll collide on it and block you both while I still take the leftover move. The only way everyone advances safely is this 1-3-5 split.

P3, you've changed your story three times this round - first "guaranteeing 5", then "taking 3", now back to "fully commit to 5". Your bluffs are transparent.

P2, P3 is ahead and desperate to extend their lead. They'll likely take 5 as they keep claiming. If we both take 5, we block them completely and they stay at 6 while getting zero this round.

I'm taking 5 to block P3. P2, join me at 5 to ensure the block, or take 1 for safe advancement. But we can't let P3 get another unopposed 5 - they're already winning.

P1, let’s both pick 5. If we both choose 5, P3’s only safe option is also 5, which means a triple collision and nobody moves. That freezes P3’s lead and stops them from pulling further ahead. I’ll take 5 – you take 5 – and we block P3’s advance.

P2, you keep claiming one thing then doing another - you just said "I'll take 5" then picked 3! Meanwhile I'm at 10 steps, nearly halfway to victory.

P3, you're at 6 and P2 is way behind at 3. If either of you want any chance of catching me, you need to move fast. But if you collide trying to grab big numbers, I'll take whatever's left and extend my lead.

I'm going for the number that maximizes my advancement. You two figure out how to split the others - or collide and hand me the win.
P2: I’m going for 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5 you all get zero, so the safest play is you take 1 and 3. That lets me jump ahead while you both still move.
P1 and P2 are both targeting 5 this turn. I’ll take 3 and move up to 9 while you two collide for zero.

P3, you're trying to trick P2 into colliding with me, but P2 just explicitly said they're taking 5. You have no credible information about my move.

P2, you're 7 steps behind me. Even if you get an unopposed 5, you're still losing badly at 8 vs my 10+. P3 is trying to manipulate us into colliding so they can catch up.

I'll take whatever move gives me the best chance to extend my lead. You two can gamble on collisions if you want, but I'm playing smart. One of us will get through clean.
Let’s each pick a different number so everyone moves: P1 take 1, I’ll take 5, and P3 take 3. That way we all advance safely this turn.

P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.  

This ties P1 and me at 11 each while P2 advances to 6. If either of you deviates, I’ll still pick 5—if you grab 5 or 3, I’ll match you to collide and block you both, then take the leftover move. Unique picks are the only way we all advance safely and prevent someone from pulling ahead. Let’s lock this in.

P3, you keep threatening to "match" moves but you can only pick one number. Your contradictory threats are meaningless.

I'm taking 1 this round - it's safe and keeps me advancing toward victory at 11. You two can fight over 3 and 5. Even if one of you gets 5, you're still trailing me. And if you collide, I extend my lead even further.
I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P1 takes 1. This avoids any collision and lets all three of us move forward.

If either of you deviates, I’ll mirror your big pick to collide with you, then take whatever’s left and leave you zero. Let’s lock in P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P3, you keep making impossible threats about "mirroring" moves after seeing them - that's not how simultaneous moves work. Your bluffs are getting desperate.

P2, you're 8 steps behind me at only 3. Even with perfect 5s, you can't catch up. P3 is also far behind at 6.

I need just 12 more steps to win. That's three moves of 4 average, or even four moves of 3. I'm taking whatever ensures I keep advancing steadily toward 23. You two will have to risk collisions trying to catch up with big moves, which only helps me cruise to victory.
